snippet.description:
From centuries-old specimens to entirely new types of specialized collections like frozen tissues and genomic data, the Museum's scientific collections (with more than 33,000,000 specimens and artifacts) form an irreplaceable record of life on Earth, the span of geologic time, and knowledge about our vast universe.

Shelf Life is a collection for curious minds—opening doors, pulling out drawers, and taking the lids off some of the incredible, rarely-seen items in the American Museum of Natural History.
Over the next year, Shelf Life will explore topics like specimen preparation, learn why variety is vital, and meet some of the people who work in the Museum collections. 

For more, visit http://www.amnh.org/ShelfLife

snippet.description:

snippet.description:

For more about this iconic prehistoric fish, and the longstanding mystery that was put to rest when the Museum’s specimen was dissected, head over to the episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/shelf-life-six-ways-to-prepare-a-coelacanth

snippet.title: Six Ways To Prepare a Coelacanth - Shelf Life #3

snippet.description:
Ninety years after it was first collected, Mammal #66753 from Ecuador was finally recognized as a new species. Researcher Miguel Pinto tells the story of how a Museum specimen helped lead to the discovery of the olinguito, and Curator Nancy Simmons discusses the importance of holotypes.

For more about how new species are discovered in collections—and in the field—head over to the episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/shelf-life-skull-of-the-olinguito

Shelf Life is a collection for curious minds—opening doors, pulling out drawers, and taking the lids off some of the incredible, rarely seen items in the American Museum of Natural History. Over the next year, Shelf Life will explore topics like specimen preparation, learn why variety is vital, and meet some of the people who work in the Museum collections. Videos roll out monthly, and Episode 5 will premiere on March 20, 2015.

For more, visit http://www.amnh.org/ShelfLife

snippet.title: How To Time Travel To a Star - Shelf Life #5

snippet.description:
You could easily mistake foraminifera fossils for flecks of dust, but these tiny specimens hold big insights about Earth’s climate. Scientific Assistant Bushra Hussaini, researcher Ellen Thomas, Curator Neil Landman, and intern Shaun Mahmood are preserving this invaluable collection.

For more about how fossil organisms reveal the record of a changing Earth, head over to the episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/shelf-life-06-the-tiniest-fossils

This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant No. 1203394. PI: Neil Landman. Co-PI: Ruth O’Leary.

The Microfossil Digitization and Rehousing Project team would like to thank volunteer Linda Scalbom.

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Voyage of the Giant Squid - Shelf Life #8

snippet.description:
Sexologist Alfred Kinsey’s first love was the tiny gall wasp. His incredible collection—7.5 million wasps and the plant galls from which they hatch—is now housed at the Museum, and a case study for why having so many specimens can unlock important avenues of research.

For more about how Alfred Kinsey’s work with gall wasps informed his more famous research on human sexuality, head over to the episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/episode-09-kinsey-s-wasps

Image of Alfred Kinsey with galls, courtesy of The Kinsey Institute, http://www.kinseyinstitute.org.

snippet.title: Kinsey's Wasps - Shelf Life #9

snippet.description:
Discovering a dinosaur is just the first step. Paleontologists Sterling Nesbitt, Mark Norell, and Danny Barta tell the story behind the Museum's treasure trove of Triassic fossils from Ghost Ranch, New Mexico.

For more about how fossils are prepared for the Museum’s collection, head over to the episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/episode-10-the-dinosaurs-of-ghost-ranch

snippet.title: Green Grow the Salamanders - Shelf Life #11

snippet.description:
Six tales of extinctions, and what collections can tell us about life on our planet. Six researchers share 60-second stories about organisms that may be gone, but not forgotten.

For more about the mass extinctions that shaped life on Earth, head over to the episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/episode-12-six-extinctions-in-six-minutes

snippet.title: Six Extinctions In Six Minutes - Shelf Life Episode #12

snippet.description:
Join a 1920s fossil-hunting expedition to the Gobi Desert with Roy Chapman Andrews, then step into the Museum’s modern-day collections with paleontologist Mike Novacek to discover how these finds are studied today.

Check out a quick primer on how to watch 360 video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXO5bnyBhzo
 
Go behind the scenes to see Gobi fossils researchers are working with today: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XTyNGtadjq0

For more discoveries in the desert, visit our episode website: http://www.amnh.org/amnh2/shelf-life/discoveries-in-the-desert

For Shelf Life’s Season 2, pack your bags for adventure. Explore fantastic stories from more than a century of expeditions that helped build the Museum's 33 million specimens and artifacts—and find out what scientists are still uncovering about them today.

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Nothing But the Tooth - Shelf Life #13

snippet.description:
The island of Cuba is a key piece of the puzzle for two bat researchers trying to understand biodiversity in the Caribbean. Find out why on an expedition with mammalogists J. Angelo Soto-Centeno and Gilberto Silva Taboada, joined by Ana Luz Porzecanski, director of the Museum's Center for Biodiversity and Conservation.

For more about tracking animal populations through time, visit our episode website: 
http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/research-repeat

And visit the Museum's new special exhibition ¡Cuba!, open now through August 13, 2017: http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/cuba

For Shelf Life’s Season 2, pack your bags for adventure. Explore fantastic stories from more than a century of expeditions that helped build the Museum’s 33 million specimens and artifacts—and find out what scientists are still uncovering about them today.

For more, visit our series website: http://www.amnh.org/ShelfLife

snippet.title: Into the Island of Bats - Shelf Life #14

snippet.description:
Meet the shamans of snowy Siberia with the Jesup North Pacific Expedition—one of the largest anthropology expeditions of all time. Curator Laurel Kendall tells the story of how the Museum’s pre-Soviet collections remain vital to the preservation of a living culture. 

Check out a quick primer on how to watch 360 video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXO5bnyBhzo 
 
Go behind the scenes to see conservators working in the Division of Anthropology’s Objects Conservation Laboratory: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IZuYhwozw9Y

For Shelf Life’s Season 2, pack your bags for adventure. Explore fantastic stories from more than a century of expeditions that helped build the Museum’s 33 million specimens and artifacts—and find out what scientists are still uncovering about them today.

snippet.title: The Guts and Glory of Object Conservation - Shelf Life #15

snippet.description:
What do crocodiles and leopards have in common? Century-old specimens of both are helping to decode the biodiversity of ecosystems that are under threat today. Researcher Evon Hekkala and Curator Joel Cracraft help unravel the mystery of cryptic species.

#crypticspecies #endangered #collections #biodiversity

Find out what goes into—and sometimes comes out of—making dioramas on our episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/discoveries-in-dioramas  

Congo footage courtesy of WCS Congo / Zanne Labuschagne
www.wcscongoblog.org | www.vimeo.com/wcscongo

For Shelf Life’s Season 2, pack your bags for adventure. Explore fantastic stories from more than a century of expeditions that helped build the Museum’s 33 million specimens and artifacts—and find out what scientists are still uncovering about them today.

For more stories from behind the scenes, visit our series website: http://www.amnh.org/ShelfLife

snippet.title: Tales From the Cryptic Species - Shelf Life #16

snippet.description:
Vladimir Nabokov is best known for his literary masterpiece Lolita, but next to writing, his great passion was the study of moths and butterflies. Curatorial Assistant Suzanne Rab Green tells the story of the author’s first road trip across the U.S., where he drew inspiration and collected specimens along the way.

For a timeline of Nabokov’s 1941 trip, including butterflies and vintage postcards from the route, visit our episode website: http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/nabokov-s-butterflies-360. 

Check out a quick primer on how to watch 360 video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXO5bnyBhzo 
 
#VR #360 #Nabokov #butterflies #Lepidoptera #roadtrip

snippet.title: Nabokov's Butterflies - Shelf Life 360

snippet.description:
Volcanoes have enthralled and terrified humans for centuries. Today, researchers are trying to uncover the secret “ingredients” behind dangerous eruptions. Expeditions to Mt. Vesuvius—one of the world’s best-known volcanoes—and Alaska’s Mt. Saint Augustine provide specimens that can be compared to materials synthesized in the lab. Understanding what makes one volcano’s magma so much more explosive than another may one day help us avoid volcanic disasters.

#volcanoes #eruptions #magma #lava #science #geology

Visit AMNH.org for a transcript of this episode: 
https://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/episode-18-under-the-volcanoes

Join a volcanic expedition from the Museum’s past, and learn more about Curator Jim Webster’s work on our website: https://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/volcanoes-from-field-to-lab

snippet.description:

snippet.title: Science Collections For Curious Minds - Shelf Life

snippet.description:
Here on Earth, volcanic eruptions are dramatic manifestations of our dynamic planet. Elsewhere in our solar system, awe-inspiring extraterrestrial volcanoes—both active and extinct—provide clues to planetary formation and hints of how life may have formed. Join us for a 360° virtual expedition to Mars’s massive shield volcano Olympus Mons, the violent surface of Jupiter’s moon Io, and the icy jets of Saturn’s moon Enceladus.

#space #volcanoes #cryovolcanoes #eruptions #spacevolcanoes #science #Moon #Mars #Io #Enceladus #Vesta #astronomy #geology

Join a volcanic expedition here on Earth, and learn more about the Museum’s volcanic research on our website: https://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/volcanoes-from-field-to-lab 

For Shelf Life’s Season 2, pack your bags for adventure. Explore fantastic stories from more than a century of expeditions that helped build the Museum’s 33 million specimens and artifacts—and find out what scientists are still uncovering about them today.
